description: From Middle English gadden (“to hurry, to rush about”).

entries.meaning: One who roams about idly; a gadabout.

verbs.description: gad (third-person singular simple present gads, present participle gadding, simple past and past participle gadded)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To move from one location to another in an apparently random and frivolous manner.
(of cattle) To run with the tail in the air, bent over the back, usually in an attempt to escape the warble fly.

description: From Middle English gade (“a fool, simpleton, rascal, scoundrel; bastard”), from Old English gada (“fellow, companion, comrade, associate”), from Proto-West Germanic *gadō, from Proto-Germanic *gadô, *gagadô (“companion, associate”), related to Proto-West Germanic *gaduling (“kinsman”). Cognate with Dutch gade (“spouse”), German Gatte (“male spouse, husband”). See also gadling.

entries.meaning: (Northern England, Scotland, derogatory) A greedy and/or stupid person.
examples: Ye greedy ged, ye have taken the very breath out o' me.

description: From Middle English gad, gadde, borrowed from Old Norse gaddr (“goad, spike”), from Proto-Germanic *gazdaz (“spike, rod, stake”).

entries.meaning: (especially UK, US, dialect) A goad, a sharp-pointed rod for driving cattle, horses, etc, or one with a whip or thong on the end for the same purpose.
(UK, US, dialect) A rod or stick, such as a fishing rod or a measuring rod.
examples: And we'll prepare our limber gads,
Lang lines, and braw brass wheels;

entries.meaning: (especially mining) A pointed metal tool for breaking or chiselling rock.
examples: Frank was able to keep his eyes open long enough to check his bed with a miner's gad and douse the electric lamp
they sette uppon hym and drew oute their swerdys to have slayne hym – but there wolde no swerde byghte on hym more than uppon a gadde of steele, for the Hyghe Lorde which he served, He hym preserved.

entries.meaning: (dated, metallurgy) An indeterminate measure of metal produced by a furnace, sometimes equivalent to a bloom weighing around 100 pounds.
examples: Twice a day a 'gad' of iron, i.e., a bloom weighing 1 cwt. was produced, which took from six to seven hours.

entries.meaning: A spike on a gauntlet; a gadling.
